texts.shortText: Small rounded beetle with very dark brown to black head and smooth black thorax. Antennae bear prominent terminal knobs. Elytra light brown and each marked with 9 strongly-pitted longitudinal grooves.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Namibia to Western Cape.

Commonly found on sandy beaches along the west coast, where it most often found sheltering under decaying seaweeds along the driftline, especially kelps. Also occurs inland, where it is associated with dung.

Both adults and larvae are present throughout the year. The adults scavenge on decomposing material. Larvae are short-legged and white and are mostly predatory, but may also feed on material oozing from decaying kelp.
Feed on decomposing material, especially rotting kelps.

The larvae have a lifespan of about 40 days. Pupae are found on the top few cm of sand or soil and are enclosed in earthen cells constructed by the larvae. Pupation takes 9-12 days. Newly emerged adults are pale yellowish and take a few days to assume the normal darker colouration.

There are at least 70 species of Hydrophilidae in South Africa, most of which are associated with water or damp habitats (as the family name suggests). Two species of Cercyon have been recorded among rotting kelps on beaches, the other species, C. gigas being dark brown with narrow longitudinal black stripes along its elytra.

Prins, AJ (1984). Morphological and biological notes on some South African arthropods associated with decaying organic matter. 2. The predatory families Carabidae, Hydrophilidae, Histeridae, Staphylinidae and Silphidae (Coleoptera). Annals of the South African Museum, 92 (4), 295-356. (p. 305)
